nodes.bodyText: Asserts are often disabled, it's better to make it more explicit I think - can add an init method and call it in a static initializer instead.
So you mean adding RequestContextUtil.init() and call it from the static initializer of ClientFactory? If init() doesn't do anything, isn't it disabled as well?
Ah, you meant making contextStorage not final and initializing in init().
Ah nah I meant an empty method - it would still trigger classload and is a but clearer at the call site init() as a verb rather than just storage()
Not sure if it's better but RequestContextUtil could still expose the same static API as before without returning ContextStorage

Think this is fine as is but for reference I notice grpc accepts a reference to the current context as well, maybe it helps catch bugs.
https://grpc.github.io/grpc-java/javadoc/io/grpc/Context.Storage.html#detach-io.grpc.Context-io.grpc.Context-

I think it's helpful to have a flag to to set the desired implementation class name to help with this situation without needing to hack with the jar
Actually maybe it's fine to crash instead of warn too since it's so dangerous to use a wrong storage.

I think it's helpful to have a flag to to set the desired implementation class name to help with this situation without needing to hack with the jar

So you mean just providing a flag instead of SPI? or both?
Both - the flag would be when the SPI is ambiguous but usually there'd just be 0-1 SPI providers and no need for flag.
Think it's better to crash than fallback. As long as there is a flag to set the storage class (so could set it to default if really desired) it seems safer than a possibly ignored warning.
assert -> explicit initialization call
I'd put this in a static block in this class instead of here. Mostly same affect but clearer it's a one-time initialization
Will do, thanks!
Should this be RequestContextStorage?

Maybe threadLocal(), because the default storage changes based on flag/SPI?

Ah I was thinking instead of loading directly from the flag, we'd use the flag to disambiguate among the different providers in this case. I guess we can do both though

Ah, I guess I totally misunderstood. 🤣
So you meant when multiple providers exist (e.g com.x.AProvider, io.x.BProvider...), if the flag is io.x.BProvider, then we should choose the BProvider class. Right?

So I think we should choose one of them instead of throwing an exception. 😉
